slides.title: Lesson 1: Introduction to Dynamics
slides.content:
Dynamics is the branch of physics that studies the relationship between motion and the forces that cause it. A force can change the velocity of an object, meaning it can cause acceleration. The SI unit of force is the **Newton (N)**, where:

$$1 \; N = 1 \; \text{kg} \cdot \text{m/s}^2$$

This means that one Newton is the force required to accelerate a 1 kg mass by 1 m/s². When solving dynamics problems, it is important to always choose a reference frame and use clear **free body diagrams (FBDs)** to represent the forces acting on objects.

slides.title: Lesson 2: Forces and Free Body Diagrams
slides.content:
A **Free Body Diagram (FBD)** is a sketch that shows all the forces acting on an object. Each force is drawn as an arrow pointing in the direction that the force acts. Common forces include:

- **Gravity** ($$F_g = mg$$)
- **Normal force** (support force from a surface)
- **Tension** (pull from ropes or strings)
- **Friction** (opposes motion)
- **Applied force** (any external push or pull)

The **net force** is found by adding all the forces together as vectors:

$$F_{\text{net}} = \sum F$$

According to Newton's Second Law:

$$F_{\text{net}} = ma$$

where *m* is the mass and *a* is the acceleration.

slides.question: What is the purpose of a free body diagram?

slides.title: Lesson 3: Newton's Three Laws of Motion
slides.content:
Sir Isaac Newton proposed three fundamental laws of motion:

1. **First Law (Law of Inertia):** An object will remain at rest, or continue moving at constant velocity, unless acted upon by a net external force.

2. **Second Law:** The net force on an object is equal to its mass multiplied by its acceleration:
   $$F_{\text{net}} = ma$$

3. **Third Law:** For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Forces always come in pairs.

Examples:
- Pushing a wall: the wall pushes back on you with equal force.
- Rocket propulsion: the rocket pushes exhaust gases backward, and the gases push the rocket forward.

slides.question: Which law: object keeps moving unless force applied?

slides.title: Lesson 4: Force of Gravity
slides.content:
The **force of gravity** is the pull that Earth exerts on objects:

$$F_g = mg$$

where:
- *m* = mass of the object (kg)
- *g* = acceleration due to gravity (9.8 m/s² near Earth’s surface)

Gravity always acts downward, toward the center of Earth. It does not depend on whether the object is moving or stationary. For example, a 10 kg box experiences a gravitational force of:

$$F_g = (10)(9.8) = 98 \; N$$

slides.question: Acceleration due to gravity on Earth?

slides.title: Lesson 5: Forces at Angles and Components
slides.content:
When a force is applied at an angle, it can be broken into horizontal and vertical components:

$$F_x = F \cos \theta$$
$$F_y = F \sin \theta$$

This is important when combining multiple forces. For example, pushing a box at a 30° angle with 100 N of force gives:

- $$F_x = 100 \cos 30° = 86.6 \; N$$
- $$F_y = 100 \sin 30° = 50 \; N$$

Always resolve angled forces into components before applying Newton’s laws.

slides.title: Lesson 6: The Normal Force
slides.content:
The **normal force** ($$F_N$$) is the supporting force exerted by a surface, always perpendicular to that surface. Examples:

- On a flat surface: $$F_N = mg$$
- On an incline at angle θ: $$F_N = mg \cos \theta$$

The normal force balances part (or all) of the gravitational force, depending on the situation.

slides.title: Lesson 7: Tension in Ropes
slides.content:
The **tension force** ($$T$$) acts along ropes, strings, or cables. In an ideal rope (massless and frictionless), the tension is the same throughout the entire rope. Tension always pulls away from the object, along the rope. For example, to hold a 10 kg mass at rest:

$$T = F_g = mg = (10)(9.8) = 98 \; N$$

slides.question: Tension in massless rope same throughout?
Tension needed to hold 10 kg mass?

slides.title: Lesson 8: Friction Forces
slides.content:
Friction is a force that resists motion between two surfaces. There are two main types:

- **Static friction** (before motion starts):
  $$F_s \leq \mu_s F_N$$

- **Kinetic friction** (while sliding):
  $$F_k = \mu_k F_N$$

where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction (depends on surfaces in contact). Usually, $$\mu_s > \mu_k$$, meaning it is harder to start motion than to keep it going.

slides.title: Lesson 9: Inclined Planes
slides.content:
On an incline at angle θ, gravity can be split into components:

- Parallel to slope: $$F_{\parallel} = mg \sin \theta$$
- Perpendicular to slope: $$F_{\perp} = mg \cos \theta$$

The net force down the slope is:

$$F_{\text{net}} = mg \sin \theta - F_{\text{friction}}$$

slides.question: Sliding block down incline: net force = ?

slides.title: Lesson 10: Pulleys and Connected Objects
slides.content:
Pulleys are used to change the **direction** of tension forces. In an ideal pulley (massless and frictionless), the tension is the same on both sides of the rope. For connected masses, both objects share the same acceleration. To solve pulley problems:

1. Draw an FBD for each mass.
2. Write Newton’s Second Law ($$F = ma$$) for each object.
3. Use the rope constraint (same acceleration) to connect equations.

slides.title: Lesson 11: Uniform Circular Motion
slides.content:
An object moving in a circle at constant speed is constantly changing direction, which means it is accelerating. This acceleration is called **centripetal acceleration**, and it requires a **centripetal force**:

$$F_c = \frac{mv^2}{r}$$

where:
- *m* = mass of object
- *v* = speed
- *r* = radius of circle

The force is always directed **toward the center** of the circle. It can be provided by tension, friction, or gravity, depending on the situation.

slides.title: Lesson 12: Forces Unit Summary
slides.content:
Key takeaways:

- Forces are **vectors**, and the **net force** causes acceleration: $$F = ma$$.
- Newton’s **three laws** explain how forces and motion are related.
- The most common forces are **gravity, tension, normal force, and friction**.
- Applications include **inclined planes, pulleys, and circular motion**.
- The first step in solving any dynamics problem is to draw a clear **Free Body Diagram (FBD)**.

slides.question: First step in solving dynamics problems?
